bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 25, 1900

div1.p: Reed sees the wreck of the Maine in Havana harbor and gives his opinion of the sinking.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 25, 1900
div1.p:
We have just
passed El Morro, Cabañas & several
other Spanish fortifications and are
now at anchor near the floating
dry Dock- The City of Havana from
the shore is certainly very beau-
tiful, but as I write I see the
wreck of the Maine not more than
400 yards away, and it makes
my very blood to boil- The
whole Island wasn't worth
the loss of those brave men
& that gallant ship- Damn
every Spaniard that ever lived!
Our journey down was very
pleasant, but your old Mr
Mantee couldn't stand the motion
of the ship- I felt very well &
ate quite a hearty dinner, but
a half hour later, that dinner
was lost forever! Friday, I passed
a miserable day- Saturday, I was
a little better & was quite com-
fortable on Sunday- Only 2 meals
however, since I started from
old Point, & lost the first one!
Every body aboard the ship was
as kind as possible, but that
couldn't remove that everlasting
feeling of goneness! I have
made up my mind that I am
not a good sailor- The Harbor
here is very pretty with the
ships of various nations at
anchor, & the little Cuban sail
boats gliding here & there-
The surrounding hills are very
graceful & pretty- Coming in
from the sea, the shore line &
interior was very striking with
its fringe of green & blue
mountains; but again I see
the wreck of the Maine & I
hate the whole Island!

Certainly every American ship
that enters this Harbor, should
sail around that wreck, dip
its colors & fire a salute!
I never saw anything that so
touched my inner nature, as
the sight of those bare ribs
of iron & her foremast sticking
out of the water- What a mon-
ument our Countrymen should
place there to mark forever
that act of Spanish treachery!
Well, we will go ashore to-morrow
& I will expect to see Dar-
boy, as his camp is near Genl
Brooks' headquarters- I am
so anxious to see the dear
boy once more! The boat
that takes the mail is along-
side & I must close this
letter- Will write just as soon
as I know how long we are
to be here - with love & kisses
for my precious wifie & daughter-
I saw this to Washington, for
fear that you may already
have left Norfolk-

Again love & kisses for my
darling-
